newsarticle.author: Sampson Lyrret
newsarticle.headline: Take advantage of all 1999 tax changes
newsarticle.content:
WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- The good news for U.S. investors is their taxes are falling. The bad news is their taxes -- and their investments -- are getting much more complicated.

As the end of the year approaches, most taxpayers are just beginning to look at the details of the 1996 tax bill, which includes many goodies for middle-class Americans who save for retirement, education or their children.

It will cut net taxes by 95 billion over the next five years, and 275 billion over 10 years. Key changes include:

  • A 500 per child tax credit;
  • A gradual increase in the threshold for estate taxes to 1 million;
  • Various education incentives, including a tax credit of up to 1,500 for two years of college and a new education savings account;
  • New individual retirement accounts, or IRAs. See Full story

However, the biggest change will help the owners of stocks, bonds and other productive property. Congress agreed to lower the capital gains tax rates as part of the Balanced Budget Act. To balance the budget, Congress was counting on massive redemptions of capital gains in the next few years. So far, however, there is little evidence of a massive sell-off.

"I have not seen or heard of any great rush to the market to sell," said Larry Rabun, national director of estate planning services at Deloitte & Touche. "You're in the market for the long haul ... Don't run out and start selling securities because you're scared or because of tax reasons."

Taking stock

Regardless of the ultimate impact on the economy, the new tax law is giving high income taxpayers a good reason to re-evaluate their whole financial strategy.

Tax dodges are possible because capital gains get tax-preferred treatment over other forms of capital income like interest payments, dividends or rent, which are taxed as ordinary income at rates as high as 39.6 percent. By contrast, capital gains on investments held at least 18 months will be taxed at a maximum of 20 percent. (See chart in left margin.)

Stephen Corrick, a tax partner with Arthur Anderson, said the new law provides opportunities for "tax-rate arbitrage." His firm advises investors to consider the tax consequences of all their investments and to make changes based on their own risk-reward profile.

Some tax-saving tactics suggested by Arthur Anderson include:

  • Shift growth investments (with possible capital gains) out of qualified retirement programs and replace them with lower-risk investments that pay dividends or interest. Retirement plans don't give investors payouts in capital gains, so the new rates don't help.
  • Asking employers to put some compensation income in stock options that can be sold at a gain.
  • Time stock sales to come just before dividends are paid to take advantage of the boost in price without getting saddled with the ordinary income from the dividend.
  • Take early distributions from qualified plans and put the proceeds into growth investments.

Risky business

Many of these tactics involve switching into higher risk investments, which are more likely to realize capital gains. Traditionally, blue-chip stocks, particularly utilities that pay regular dividends, have been some of the safest investments for people who want a steady stream of income.

The new law favors investments in higher risk companies over the old reliables, continuing a long-term trend away from dividends and toward capital gains.

"There is an added incentive to invest in stocks and other assets that are expected to appreciate because when you cash out your gains, the tax bite may be less," says accounting firm KPMG.

Many corporations have been under pressure for some time to "increase shareholder value," which is code for rewarding investors in capital gains rather than in dividends. For years, many corporations have bought their own stock with their retained earnings, rather than passing them on as dividends.

New pitfalls?

But critics of the new law and some financial planners say the new rates could lead to new tax shelters and schemes that will simply shift money from heavily taxed investments to lower taxed investments, with no net gain to the economy.

"Despite what some politicians and pundits would have us believe, the impact of this legislation on the economy is likely to be small," says accounting and financial planning firm Arthur Anderson.

"New capital gains tax loopholes and corporate tax breaks will inspire lawyers and accountants to invent a new generation of tax avoidance schemes for their clients," says the liberal nonprofit organization Citizens for Tax Justice. "These are likely to spur tax-motivated, economically foolish investments at the expense of good ones."
